thread.section_title: Central Florida Political Pulse - Orlando Sentinel
thread.title: Court pushes back arguments as redistricting schedules clash
thread.title_full: Court pushes back arguments as redistricting schedules clash

author: Gray Rohrer
title: Court pushes back arguments as redistricting schedules clash
text:
Court pushes back arguments as redistricting schedules clash Gray Rohrer Arguments in Florida congressional redistricting case moved to Nov. 10 
TALLAHASSEE – The Florida Supreme Court issued an order Friday pushing back oral arguments in Florida’s congressional redistricting case to Nov. 10. 
The court originally scheduled them for Nov. 2, but the Legislature will still be in the middle of a special session to redraw 40 state Senate districts. The Senate redistricting session is scheduled to start Monday and end Nov. 6. 
Florida House lawyers asked the court Thursday to move the oral arguments back because they’ll be busy analyzing the different iterations of Senate maps proposed by lawmakers and won’t have enough time to prepare for the congressional case. 
In that case, Florida’s 27 congressional districts were thrown out by the Florida Supreme Court in July because of partisan gerrymandering on the part of Republican legislative leaders. That decision ordered the Legislature to redraw the maps but still retained jurisdiction for the courts. 
After the House and Senate failed to reach an agreement on new district configurations during an August special session, a Leon Circuit Court judge ruled in favor of maps drawn by the plaintiffs in the case, left-leaning groups Common Cause and the League of Women Voters. 
That decision will be under review during the oral arguments.
